As we know, Donald Trump's inner circle is filled with family and friends and business associates, many of whom happen to be very wealthy people with complicated investment portfolios.
Carl Icahn is President Trump's special adviser on regulatory reform.
He's also a billionaire investor in some of America's most heavily regulated industries.
Here's NPR's Peter Overby.
Carl Icahn doesn't hold back.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Some people make a living studying artificial intelligence.
I make it studying natural stupidity.
And what the EPA is doing is just naturally stupidity.
Icahn spoke with CNNMoney back in March.
His interest in EPA has a lot to do with the company he owns - CVR Energy.
It's got an oil refinery in Texas.
And EPA has got rules to make refineries and other pollution sources pay for the pollution they generate.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Capriciously, the EPA has decided to penalize these businesses.
Industry hopes were high that Icahn would change the rules.
CVR stock nearly doubled in value.
But the change hasn't happened, and the stock price has eased back.
Icahn and Trump, both from Queens, go way back together as friends and sometimes rivals.
Early in the campaign, Icahn made a video that effectively previewed Trump's message that the country was like broken companies he'd seen.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We need a president that can move Congress.
And I think Donald Trump could do it.
I disagree with him on certain issues and certainly would talk to him more.
But this is what this country needs, somebody to wake it up.
They would pass down their family stories.
The men would teach the sons the stories of the family and their past, as he would show them how to carve.
And then the molds would go into the kitchen where the women would repeat the stories to the girls, as they taught them how to bake.
So, it really was a family tradition.
Botchlet is a fourth generation Springerle baker and she's transformed her love of the cookies into a business.
She runs a small bakery and cafe called The Springerle House in Strasburg, Pennsylvania.
It's where she spends much of her time during the busy month of December, when hundreds of orders pour in from across the country and around the globe.
We've shipped them to Paris.
We've shipped them to Germany.
We've shipped them to a little village in England.
(SOUNDBITE OF A RINGING PHONE)
Good afternoon, Springerle House.
Some customers will even drive for miles to pick up their orders in person.
Clare Highim is from Downingtown Pennsylvania, nearly 30 miles away.
They're a lot better looking than cookies I make, let's put it that way - and so different.
This is a lost art.

Traditionally, the cookies are flavored with anise, which gives a slight black licorice taste, and their smell can bring back powerful memories for some customers, like Jane McKee, who grew up with them.
The fragrance hit me coming in the door, and it's just like walking back in time.
Botchlet believes the true appeal of the cookies is that they remind people of a time when the world moved at a much slower pace.
And I think it puts people to mind of old traditions, old times with family, quality time spent, and gifts that were homemade and had heart.
For NPR News, I'm Marie Cusick in Strasburg, Pennsylvania.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
This is NPR News.
On yesterday's program, we shared the story of New Orleans resident Brenda Morris.
Her mother needs dialysis and her brother, who is ill with cancer, needs oxygen.
They and several other relatives stayed in their home through the hurricane.
Today, we follow up with Brenda's sister, Joyce Morris.
So far, the family hasn't gotten any outside help.
NPR's Farai Chideya has more.
Joyce, how have things gone since yesterday?
Well, her feet are starting to swell now.
Your mother's feet?
Yeah.
And we've been checking her pressure periodically to see if everything is OK.
So I heard a baby in the background.
How many of your relatives are there with you?
Eighteen.
Why didn't you evacuate?
Because we didn't have the provisions to.
You thought it would be worse for you if you left than if you stayed?
Yes.
Have you seen any patrols near our house, any, you know...
No.
I walked to the convention center and they going to start evacuating people out here, bringing them to Texas by bus.
So you walked to the convention center.
How far is that for you?
If you look at it, it's about a good six, seven blocks.
So you're very close to it.
Yes.
And they didn't have any officials that could help you with the medical supplies there?
No.
As far as my brother on oxygen, they should have, you know, at least--try to give him at least some oxygen.
How many hours of oxygen does he have left and what's going to happen if he runs out?
He has about three.
Three hours.
And could he possibly die if he doesn't have the oxygen?
He probably can because he's a cancer patient.
Are you planning to evacuate to Houston?
Oh, yes.
They say be prepared to stay at least as month or so.
